citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of Thiobacillus aquaesulis sp. nov., a novel facultatively autotrophic moderate thermophile

p.s: Description of Thiobacillus aquaesulis sp. nov.

Thiobacillus aquaesulis (a.quae.su'lis.L.n. aquae, waters; L.n. Sulis, pertaining to the Temple of Sulis Minerva (Minerva, the Roman goddess of wisdom); M.L. adj. aquaesulis, from the waters of Sulis Minerva)

THe description of Thiobacillus aquaesulis given here is based on the type strain which has been deposited with Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Göttingen, FRG (DSM 4255) and the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC 43788).
Cells are Gram-negative, motile, non spore forming, short rods 0.3 x 0.9 μm, and contain some polyphosphate inclusions.
The organism is facultatively heterotrophic on complex media (yeast extract or nutrient broth), but unable to grow on common sugars, organic acids, formate or methylamine, as single substrates.
It is autotrophic and chemolithotrophic, using the oxidation of thiosulphate, trithionate and tetrathionate for growth.
In liquid batch culture in thiosulphate medium sulphur precipitation and a drop in pH without tetrathionate accumulation, occur.
Chemostat cultures do not accumulate sulphur or other intermediates during growth on thiosulphate, trithionate or tetrathionate at pH 7.6 and 43 °C.
Initiates growth at pH 7.0-9.0 (30-55°C), dropping pH to 6.0-7.0.
No growth at pH 6.4 or 9.4, or at 26° or 58°C.
Carbon dioxide is fixed by means of ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase.
Colonies on thiosulphate agar at 43°C are small (1-2 mm), circular, convex and smooth, becoming white or yellow with precipitated sulphur.
Capable of anaerobic autotrophic growth during thiosulphate-dependent denitrification.
Uses ammonium salts as nitrogen source.
The DNA contains 65.7 mol% G + C.
